reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I'll get in touch with you after I'm fired.
examples.ja: 会社を首になったら連絡するよ。

examples.en: I want to cut ties with you, so please never contact me again.
examples.ja: あなたとはエンを切りたいので、もう連絡してこないでください。

examples.en: Sorry, I’ve gotta go. I'll check my schedule and get back to you.
examples.ja: ごめん、行かなきゃ。予定を調べて、後で折り返し連絡するよ。

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>take along</kanji> a message and <kanji>entangle</kanji> it into the telephone. From there it buzzes off to the person in order for you <vocabulary>to contact</vocabulary> them.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Could you microwave this potato, please?
examples.ja: この芋、レンジでチンしてくれない？

examples.en: What, there are 4,000 kinds of potatoes? I didn't know that.
examples.ja: え、芋って四千種類もあるの？知らなかった。

examples.en: When we went camping, my friends and I baked potatoes in a bonfire.
examples.ja: キャンプに行った時、友達とたき火で芋を焼きました。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: I like baked potatoes.
examples.ja: 私は焼き芋が好きです。

examples.en: It's been decided that we are going to serve baked sweet potatoes at the school festival.
examples.ja: 学祭で焼き芋を出すことになりました。

examples.en: It's the season when roasted sweet potatoes taste delicious, isn't it?
examples.ja: 焼き芋が美味しい季節になりましたね。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Bake</kanji>d <kanji>potato</kanji> is actually <vocabulary>baked sweet potato</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>roasted sweet potato</vocabulary>). Although it's literally just potato, most Japanese speakers will automatically think of sweet potato when they hear this word. Yum! 🍠
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the readings from 焼く and 芋 put together.

examples.en: I made potato soup.
examples.ja: じゃが芋のスープを作りました。

examples.en: My grandmother bought us some delicious potato croquettes.
examples.ja: おばあちゃんが、美味しいじゃが芋のコロッケを買ってきてくれました。

examples.en: The skin of the potato contains vitamins, so it is better to eat a potato with the skin on, and not peel it off.
examples.ja: じゃが芋の皮にはビタミンがあるから、じゃが芋は皮はむかずに皮ごと食べる方がいいんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A じゃが <kanji>potato</kanji> is a <vocabulary>potato</vocabulary>. More specifically, a <vocabulary>white potato</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: He founded a new theater company.
examples.ja: 彼は新しい劇団を立ち上げました。

examples.en: She is a member of a famous theater company.
examples.ja: 彼女は有名な劇団の一員です。

examples.en: My goal is to join the Shiki Theater Company.
examples.ja: 劇団四季に入るのが私の目標です。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>drama</kanji> <kanji>group</kanji> is a <vocabulary>drama troupe</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>theatrical company</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Should we fill the blank space in the article with an illustration, or with an advertisement?
examples.ja: 記事の空白はイラストで埋める？それとも広告で？

examples.en: I want to bury my face in that cat's fluffy fur!
examples.ja: あの猫のモフモフに顔を埋めたい！

examples.en: I was called in on short notice to fill a shift vacancy left by a part-time student worker.
examples.ja: 学生バイトがあけたシフトの穴を埋めるために、急に来てくれって言われたんです。

examples.en: I’m sure someone’s already told you, but we buried the butcher in your yard. I hope you don’t mind.
examples.ja: きっとだれかがもう話をしてると思うんだけど、私達、あの肉屋をあんたの庭に埋めたのさ。良かったかな。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>bury</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to bury</vocabulary> as well.

埋める can also mean <vocabulary>to fill</vocabulary>, and can refer to filling a hole, vacancy, or gap. Note that this word can be used to refer to filling in figurative holes and gaps too, like a hole in one’s finances!
reading_mnemonic:
You learned this reading with the kanji, how nice for you!

However, you might notice that in addition to うめる, there's another reading too: うずめる. うめる is used for the act of burying something or filling in a hole, while うずめる is used when describing the covering or concealment of something, or when burying one's face in something (like a fluffy cat!)

examples.en: A lone frog was sitting there.
examples.ja: そこには、一匹のカエルが座っていた。

examples.en: When I woke up in the morning, there was a hamster in front of me.
examples.ja: 朝起きると、目の前にハムスターが一匹いた。

examples.en: That guy is really a loner, isn’t he?
examples.ja: アイツって、ほんと一匹狼だよなー。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>small animal</kanji> is <vocabulary>one small animal</vocabulary>. Use this to count small animals like cats and dogs.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the shortening and the rendaku.

examples.en: Please tell me what kinds of things we have for parts of speech.
examples.ja: 品詞にはどんなものがあるか教えてください。

examples.en: Today I will teach you how to distinguish parts of speech in English.
examples.ja: 今日は英語の品詞の見分け方をお教えします。

examples.en: I wrote a book about parts of speech and right now I'm thinking about how I can sell a lot of copies.
examples.ja: 品詞についての本を書いたんですが、今、どうすればたくさんの冊数を売ることができるのか考えています。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>product</kanji> of <kanji>part of speech</kanji> is more <vocabulary>part of speech</vocabulary>. Evil begets evil, so to speak.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I am not good at remembering people's faces.
examples.ja: 私は人の顔を覚えるのが苦手です。

examples.en: How can you memorize these kinds of details?
examples.ja: よくそんなに細かい事を覚えていますね。

examples.en: I learned kanji characters using WaniKani.
examples.ja: 私はワニカニを使って漢字を覚えました。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>memorize</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to memorize</vocabulary>. That shouldn't be too hard <vocabulary>to remember</vocabulary>, right?
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use one of the kun'yomi readings. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

The best way <vocabulary>to memorize</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to remember</vocabulary> something is to make up a song and play it on your <reading>oboe</reading> (おぼ). Something about playing it makes it so you can memorize anything. You're so talented.

examples.en: Those guys always have nothing but stupid conversations.
examples.ja: あの連中はいつもくだらない話ばかりしている。

examples.en: You shouldn't get close to a bunch of drunks.
examples.ja: よっぱらい連中には近づかない方がいいぜ。

examples.en: My son seems to be keeping the wrong company lately and I am a little worried.
examples.ja: うちの息子は、最近悪い連中と付き合っているみたいで、少し心配です。

meaning_mnemonic:
People you want to <kanji>take along</kanji> to the <kanji>middle</kanji> of somewhere are probably people you know pretty well. They're your <vocabulary>gang</vocabulary>, they're the <vocabulary>guys</vocabulary>.

This word often has a negative feel to it, though, as in "those guys can't be trusted" or "they're a selfish bunch".
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. As long as you know the readings for these kanji, you should be able to read this word just fine.

examples.en: Lately, I've been so busy that I haven't been able to do any reviews on WaniKani at all.
examples.ja: ここ最近、多忙で全然ワニカニのレビューができてません。

examples.en: He leads a busy life.
examples.ja: 彼は多忙な生活を送っています。

examples.en: When a guy says he's "too busy" to meet up, it's usually a lie. Even if he's busy, he can make time. The real reasons for not meeting are either "a lack of money" or "a lack of interest."
examples.ja: 男が「多忙」で会えないって言うのはウソだよ。多忙でも時間は作れるもん。会えない理由は「金がない」か「気持ちがない」かのどっちかだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: If you've had <kanji>many</kanji> <kanji>busy</kanji> days, then you're even more <vocabulary>busy</vocabulary> than you thought!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Dogs express joy by wagging their tails.
examples.ja: 犬はシッポをふって喜びを表します。

examples.en: We are happier when we share our joy with others.
examples.ja: 私たちは、他人と喜びを分かち合うことで、より幸せを感じることができます。

examples.en: This robot has no positive emotions such as joy or fun.
examples.ja: このロボットには喜びや楽しさといったポジティブな感情はありません。

meaning_mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>rejoice</kanji>, so it means <vocabulary>joy</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>delight</vocabulary>. You rejoice because there are lots of reasons for your <vocabulary>glee</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You already learned this reading when you learned 喜ぶ so you should be able to read this one too!

examples.en: The media reported the news daily.
examples.ja: マスコミはそのニュースを連日報道しました。

examples.en: This year, Hokkaido has been experiencing heavy snowfall every day.
examples.ja: 今年の北海道は連日大雪です。

examples.en: Many people came to the event day after day.
examples.ja: そのイベントには連日たくさんの人がやって来ました。

meaning_mnemonic: What happens when you <kanji>take along</kanji> a <kanji>day</kanji>? It becomes <vocabulary>every day</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I do IT related work.
examples.ja: IT関連の仕事をしています。

examples.en: Perhaps this issue is related to the previous one.
examples.ja: もしかすると、この問題は以前の問題と関連があるのかもしれません。

examples.en: That user is a movie buff and is always doing movie related posts.
examples.ja: あのユーザーは映画好きで、いつも映画関連のポストをしている。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>take along</kanji> some things that are <kanji>related</kanji>, you'll be able to understand their <vocabulary>relation</vocabulary> better.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: You need time to overcome the sadness.
examples.ja: 悲しみを乗りこえるには時間が必要です。

examples.en: The best medicine for grief is chocolate ice cream.
examples.ja: 悲しみへの一番の薬は、チョコアイスです。

examples.en: I was overcome by grief when I heard the news of Pochi's death.
examples.ja: ポチが死んだという知らせを聞いて、悲しみに打ちひしがれていました。

meaning_mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>sad</kanji>, so it means <vocabulary>sadness</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You learned this reading with 悲しむ, hooray!

examples.en: My cat sometimes opens her mouth to look in the air.
examples.ja: うちの猫はたまに口を開けて宙を見る時があります。

examples.en: Right now everything is in limbo and I have zero motivation.
examples.ja: 今は何もかもが宙ぶらりんで、やる気ゼロなんです。

examples.en: I like the face Koichi makes when he takes bills out of his pockets and throws them into the air.
examples.ja: ポケットから札束を取り出し、宙にバラまく時のコウイチの顔が好きだ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: It's rare for animals to mix breeds with one another.
examples.ja: 動物は、別の種が混血することはめったにありません。

examples.en: Koichi is a mix of Japanese and American.
examples.ja: コウイチは日本人とアメリカ人の混血です。

examples.en: In my upcoming movie, I play the role of a girl who is a mix of a vampire and a human.
examples.ja: 今度の映画では、ヴァンパイアと人間の混血の女の子の役を演じるんです。

meaning_mnemonic: If you have <kanji>mixed</kanji> <kanji>blood</kanji>, some people might say you're of <vocabulary>mixed race</vocabulary>. Own it!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: We decided to change the date.
examples.ja: 日を改めることにしました。

examples.en: You should correct that way of thinking.
examples.ja: その考え方は改めた方がいいよ。

examples.en: Just as we discussed, we revised a part of the plan.
examples.ja: 話し合った通りに計画を一部改めた。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

The kanji itself means <kanji>renew</kanji>, and this verb's meaning isn't far off. What do you do if you renew something, usually to make it better? You're going <vocabulary>to change something</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to revise something</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to correct something</vocabulary>. This verb is transitive, so it takes a direct object.

改める is a formal word for when you're actively make changes or improvements, like fixing a mistake or reforming a system. You might also use it when you decide to change your behavior or update your way of doing something.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Usually when we want <vocabulary>to change something</vocabulary>, we want to make it <reading>新た</reading> (あらた), right? Out with the old, in with the 新た, as they say.

examples.en: What was the main reason you decided to stop drinking alcohol?
examples.ja: 飲酒をやめようと思った一番の理由は何ですか？

examples.en: Drinking is expensive and bad for you, right?
examples.ja: 飲酒はお金がかかるし、体に悪いでしょう。

examples.en: I heard that guy got a minor to drink.
examples.ja: あいつ、未成年に飲酒させたらしいよ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Drink</kanji> <kanji>alcohol</kanji> is <vocabulary>drinking alcohol</vocabulary>, or just <vocabulary>drinking</vocabulary>. This always refers to alcohol though.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading of 飲 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Where's a good place for <vocabulary>drinking alcohol</vocabulary>? An <reading>inn</reading> (いん), of course!

examples.en: He is an entomologist.
examples.ja: 彼は昆虫学者です。

examples.en: One day we'll all be eating insects for breakfast.
examples.ja: いつか朝ご飯に昆虫を食べる日が来るだろう。

examples.en: My favorite insect is the antlion larva.
examples.ja: 私の一番好きな昆虫はアリジゴクです。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>insect</kanji> <kanji>insect</kanji> is... you guessed it! An <vocabulary>insect</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi of the kanji. You learned this reading for 昆 when you learned the kanji, but you haven't learned the on'yomi for 虫 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Did you know that <vocabulary>insect</vocabulary>s are <reading>Chew</reading>bacca's (ちゅう) favorite thing? He's fascinated by all types of insects, and keeps them in boxes as pets. There are a good few of them crawling around in his fur, too.

examples.en: I'd like this one to go, please.
examples.ja: これはお持ち帰りでお願いします。

examples.en: What shall we do, eat at a restaurant? Get takeout?
examples.ja: どうする、お店で食べる？お持ち帰りにする？

examples.en: Here's the take-out order for customer number two!
examples.ja: こちら、二番さんのお持ち帰りのオーダーのお品になります！

meaning_mnemonic: When you're <kanji>hold</kanji>ing food and <kanji>return</kanji>ing home with it, you're likely getting <vocabulary>takeout</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You've already learned how to read both 持つ and 帰る, so you should be able to read this as well.

examples.en: Who was the mayor two years ago again?
examples.ja: 一昨年の市長って誰だったっけ？

examples.en: I have been jogging every day since two years ago.
examples.ja: 一昨年から毎日ジョギングをしています。

examples.en: The year before last, I saw a show by the Huis Ten Bosch Revue in Huis Ten Bosch.
examples.ja: 一昨年、ハウステンボスでハウステンボス歌劇団のショーを見てきました。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 一昨日 means "day before last"? Similarly, <kanji>one</kanji> year <kanji>previous</kanji> to that <kanji>year</kanji> is the <vocabulary>year before last</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The last time you tossed something into a trash can was the <vocabulary>year before last</vocabulary>. Why? Because you got a trash can with an <reading>auto</reading>  <reading>tossi</reading>ng (おととし) feature. What amazing technology!

examples.en: This phrasing still conveys the meaning, but it sounds a bit unnatural.
examples.ja: この言い方でも意味は通じるけど、ちょっと不自然かな。

examples.en: I met him through the Internet.
examples.ja: 彼とは、インターネットを通じて知り合いました。

examples.en: Even if we don't share a common language, our hearts can still connect.
examples.ja: 言葉は通じなくても、心が通じることはあります。

examples.en: Nothing I say gets through to that person and nothing they say makes sense either; it's like talking to an alien.
examples.ja: あの人、全然話が通じないんですよ。エイリアンと話してるみたいな感覚になります。

meaning_mnemonic:
You have <kanji>pass through</kanji>, so this is <vocabulary>to pass through</vocabulary>.

This word has a bunch of different meanings, and translations will vary depending on context. In short, it's mostly used figuratively to mean that something, like communication, is passing or coming through successfully. Have a look at our common word combinations and context sentences for some example usages!
reading_mnemonic: Like other verbs that end in じる, this actually uses the on'yomi of the kanji, not kun'yomi! You learned that reading with the kanji, so you should be good to go here.

examples.en: Wow, that's amazing! As might be expected of you.
examples.ja: すごーい！流石ですね。

examples.en: Even I can't do this.
examples.ja: 流石のオレでもこれはムリだわ。

examples.en: It's just like Nic Cage to do that!
examples.ja: 流石、ニコラスケイジだね！

examples.en: I've had seven whole meetings today, so it's no wonder I'm tired.
examples.ja: ミーティングが七つもあってさ、今日は流石につかれたよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>stream</kanji> containing <kanji>stone</kanji>s is like… the most natural thing ever. It's just <vocabulary>as expected</vocabulary>. 

Note that you'll encounter this being written in kana as well, but the meaning is the same.
reading_mnemonic:
Unfortunately, the reading for this is a total exception that you'll just have to memorize, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Just <vocabulary>as expected</vocabulary>, your <reading>sauce ga</reading>l (さすが) saved the day. The dish you cooked was looking a little bare until your gal poured sauce all over it. It looked a little like a stream flowing over dry rocks when she poured the sauce. Just as you'd expect of your sauce gal.

examples.en: When I click here, the text overlaps and becomes unreadable. Do you think it's a bug?
examples.ja: ここをクリックすると、文字が上に重なるから読めなくなるんだ。バグかな？

examples.en: What should I do? My child's birthday party falls on a work day.
examples.ja: どうしよう、子どものバースデーパーティーと仕事の日が重なってしまった。

examples.en: There's not just one cause. Various factors converged to make it like this.
examples.ja: 原因は一つじゃありません。様々な要因が重なって、こうなってしまったんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
If you remember 重ねる, then you'll recognize this as the intransitive version of that verb. Literally, this means <vocabulary>to be piled up</vocabulary>, but it's often used to mean <vocabulary>to coincide</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to overlap</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to accumulate</vocabulary>.

As is often our recommendation for more complicated or hard-to-translate words like this one, check out our common word combinations and context sentences to see how this word is used!
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned that reading with 重ねる, but in case it's slipped your mind, here's a mnemonic to help you remember:

All these boxes that are <vocabulary>piled up</vocabulary> are here because you've just moved into your new <reading>casa</reading> (かさ). Congratulations! Now it's time to unpack every single box you've <vocabulary>accumulate</vocabulary>d. Have fun.

examples.en: There were roads in all directions, and I couldn't decide which to take.
examples.ja: 東西南北に道があって、どちらに行こうかまよいました。

examples.en: He looked in all directions, wondering where he should go.
examples.ja: 彼は東西南北を見回し、どこへ行けばいいのか考えました。

examples.en: Stars sparkled in all directions, and the night sky was like a jewelry box.
examples.ja: 東西南北に星がきらめき、夜空はまるで宝石箱のようでした。

examples.en: The compass will tell you which direction you are facing, east, west, south, or north.
examples.ja: コンパスを使うと、東西南北のどちらの方角を向いているのかが分かります。

meaning_mnemonic:
If something happens in the <kanji>east</kanji>, <kanji>west</kanji>, <kanji>south</kanji>, and <kanji>north</kanji>, then it's happening in <vocabulary>all directions</vocabulary>. What other directions are there? That's literally all of them.

This word usually appears in expressions like 東西南北を見る (to look in all directions). But it can also be used more literally to mean <vocabulary>east west south north</vocabulary>, aka the <vocabulary>cardinal directions</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses on'yomi readings for all four kanji. You've seen those before, so this shouldn't be too hard. Just watch out for that double rendaku — さい changes to ざい and ほく changes to ぼく.
